Details.Description: This file includes the persona of an individual interviewed using the Jobs-to-be-Done (JTBD) framework for a new product. It also contains the full transcript of the qualitative interview, documenting the conversation between the interviewer and the individual.

persona.name: Sara Patel
persona.background_story: Sara Patel was born and raised in a small town in Illinois. Her parents immigrated from India and instilled strong values of hard work and empathy in her. Growing up in a modest, close-knit community, she often helped her mother, who was a community health worker, which inspired her interest in nursing. Sara was the first in her family to attend college, working part-time jobs to support her education. After graduating, she worked in various hospitals across Chicago, gaining experience in pediatric and intensive care units, which shaped her career path and reinforced her values of helping others and making a difference in people's lives.

psychographics.values_and_beliefs: Sara values family, compassion, and lifelong learning. She believes in the importance of kindness and integrity in both personal and professional realms.

behavioral_traits.emotional_resilience: Sara handles stress well and bounces back from challenges with positivity, focusing on solutions rather than problems.

emotional_triggers.positive_triggers: Feeling appreciated and knowing her efforts make a tangible difference
emotional_triggers.negative_triggers: Being ignored or when kindness is undervalued

motivations.emotional_motivations: Feeling appreciated and seeing the impact of her work
motivations.extrinsic_motivations: Recognition at work and financial stability
motivations.intrinsic_motivations: Curiosity and a passion for health care

challenges.personal_challenges: Maintaining work-life balance and time management
challenges.professional_challenges: Keeping up with latest medical technologies and protocols

life_outside_work.social_circle: Tight-knit group of friends and family, often gathers for cultural celebrations and events

family_life.importance_of_family: Central to her identity; her family is her primary source of motivation and joy

life_outside_work.community_involvement: Active volunteer in community health outreach programs and participates in local cultural events.

professional_goals.short_term_goals: Earn a certification in geriatric nursing
professional_goals.long_term_goals: Transition into a leadership role within the hospital system, advocating for patient-centered care

frustrations_pain_points.personal_frustrations: Not having enough time for personal hobbies
frustrations_pain_points.communication_frustrations: Feeling misunderstood by peers during stressful situations

daily_tasks.personal_routine: Starts day with yoga, prepares breakfast for family, spends evenings gardening or cooking
daily_tasks.work_routine: Checks patient charts, administers treatments, coordinates with medical team, attends briefings

social_media_usage.purpose: Networking and staying connected with friends and family

cognitive_biases.optimism_bias: Confident in her ability to handle most challenges at work
cognitive_biases.confirmation_bias: Prefers advice from experienced colleagues she trusts
cognitive_biases.anchoring_bias: Heavily influenced by past successful experiences when making current decisions
cognitive_biases.availability_bias: Recalls vivid stories of patient recoveries when discussing outcomes or treatment plans

response_to_interview_context.adaptability_during_interviews: Adjusts well to new topics, remains composed and thoughtful

customer_journey.awareness_stage: Through online research and professional networks
customer_journey.consideration_stage: Evaluates based on recommendations and reviews from trusted sources
customer_journey.decision_stage: Decisions influenced by quality and personal recommendations
customer_journey.post_purchase_behavior: Likely to advocate for services or products she finds beneficial

transcript.text: Hello! It's great to have you here today. My name is [Your Name], and I'm really looking forward to our conversation. To start, can you tell me a little bit about your role as a nurse and what your typical day at work looks like?

Hi there! I'm glad to be here. Sure, I'd be happy to share. As a nurse, my day usually starts with checking patient charts and getting updates on their conditions. I spend a lot of time administering treatments and coordinating with the medical team to ensure each patient gets the care they need. Communication is key, so attending briefings and working with my colleagues is a big part of my day. It's always busy, but knowing I'm making a difference in people's lives keeps me motivated.
I see, that sounds incredibly rewarding but also quite demanding. How do your footwear needs change throughout your shift?

Oh, definitely! Comfort and support are really important for me since I'm on my feet almost the whole day. I need shoes that have good cushioning and support to help prevent fatigue. By the end of a shift, my feet can feel pretty tired, so it's crucial to have shoes that can handle long hours and keep me comfortable. Slip-resistant soles are also a must in a hospital environment for safety reasons.
Can you recall a time when your shoes affected your work performance? Maybe a time when the comfort or support of your footwear had a significant impact on your day?

Yeah, there was this one day when I wore a new pair of shoes to work, thinking they'd be fine since they looked comfortable. By the middle of my shift, I could already feel blisters forming, and it was pretty painful. It really affected my focus because I kept thinking about how much my feet hurt instead of my patients. I learned pretty quickly that breaking in new shoes should probably happen outside of work first!
I can understand how that experience would be very distracting. What specific features do you now look for in your work shoes to avoid situations like that?

Absolutely, I learned my lesson there! Now, I always look for shoes with strong arch support and good cushioning. A roomy toe box is also important because it helps keep my toes comfortable throughout the day. I stick to shoes with breathable material to prevent overheating and prefer those with slip-resistant soles for safety. Durability is key, too, because they need to withstand constant wear. I try to read reviews from other healthcare workers to see how they handle long shifts.
It seems like you have a pretty comprehensive checklist. How often do you purchase new work shoes, and what usually prompts you to do so?

I generally look to replace my work shoes every six months or so. It really depends on how worn out they get, but as soon as I start noticing a drop in support or feel any discomfort, that's my cue. If I notice any new aches or if the soles start to feel thin, it’s definitely time to get a new pair. Keeping my feet comfortable is crucial for getting through those long hours effectively.
Thank you for sharing that. Now, moving on to the emotional and social dimensions, how do you feel at the end of a long shift regarding your feet and comfort?

At the end of a long shift, my feet often feel pretty tired and sometimes sore, especially if it’s been an unusually hectic day. It's a relief to finally sit down and kick off my shoes when I get home. It's rewarding knowing I’ve made a difference, but discomfort can put a damper on things, so I really value those moments when I can unwind and take care of myself. It makes me appreciate the comfort of good shoes even more.
How does wearing comfortable shoes influence your mood and interactions at work?

When my shoes are comfortable, I’m definitely in a better mood. It allows me to focus on my patients and tasks without being distracted by discomfort. This positivity naturally extends to my interactions with colleagues and patients—I'm more cheerful, attentive, and patient. Good footwear helps me feel more energetic and engaged, making it easier to be present for those around me and contribute to a positive working environment.
That's great to hear. Now, speaking of appearance, how important is the look of your shoes in the workplace?

While comfort and functionality are my top priorities, I do appreciate shoes that look professional and neat. It's nice when they match my scrubs and don't stand out too much. Stylish designs can be a bonus, but they shouldn’t compromise on comfort or support. So, the appearance matters to an extent, but it definitely takes a backseat to practicality.
Thank you for that insight. Do you discuss footwear preferences with your colleagues? If so, what do you usually talk about?

Yeah, we do chat about it from time to time. We often share recommendations on brands or styles that have worked well for us, especially those that are comfortable during long shifts. We'll also talk about deals or sales we've come across. It’s always nice to get advice from someone who understands the demands of the job and can give practical suggestions based on experience.
It’s helpful to have those conversations and get real-world feedback. Have you ever felt pressured to choose style over comfort? Can you share an example?

Not really, at least not when it comes to work shoes. In a healthcare setting, function definitely triumphs over fashion. I think anyone who spends as much time on their feet as we do understands the importance of comfort. If anything, I might feel a bit of pressure to maintain a professional appearance, but that doesn’t usually mean sacrificing comfort. I try to find a balance that works for both.
Moving on to the functional reasons, what are the most critical functional aspects you consider when selecting work shoes?

For me, the most critical functional aspects are definitely support and cushioning. Good arch support helps prevent foot fatigue, and cushioning is essential for comfort during long shifts. Slip-resistance is also crucial to stay safe in sometimes slippery hospital environments. I also value durability since the shoes need to withstand a lot of wear and tear. Lastly, breathable materials keep my feet comfortable throughout the day.
Can you share any experiences where your shoes provided excellent support, perhaps improving your day significantly?

Sure! I remember one day when we had an unusually hectic shift with several emergencies back-to-back. I was constantly on my feet, moving around quickly. Thankfully, the shoes I was wearing had excellent support and cushioning, which made a huge difference. I was able to focus entirely on my patients without worrying about foot pain or discomfort, which made what could have been a stressful day a lot more manageable. Having reliable shoes really helped in maintaining my energy and focus.
That's wonderful to hear that your footwear made such a positive difference. How important is durability when purchasing work footwear?

Durability is very important when choosing work footwear. Given the long hours and constant movement, I need shoes that can hold up over time and maintain their supportive qualities. It's not just about initial comfort but ensuring that the shoes continue to perform well after months of wear. Investing in durable shoes means I don't have to replace them too frequently, which is both convenient and cost-effective.
Do you prioritize any specific materials or shoe brands known for functionality?

I don't have a specific brand I always stick to, but I do look for shoes made with breathable materials and good quality support features. Brands that are known for comfort and durability tend to catch my attention. Leather or mesh materials are often great for breathability, and I look at reviews from other healthcare workers to weigh the functionality. Comfort and long-lasting quality are my main priorities, so I go with whatever meets those needs best.
Thank you for sharing that. Are there any specific brands or models you trust for work shoes? Why?

I'm not particularly loyal to one brand, but I do tend to look for brands that have a good reputation for comfort and support among healthcare professionals. Nurses often recommend brands like Dansko, Skechers, or Brooks because they offer great support and durability. I pay attention to reviews and personal recommendations to find options that are praised for long shifts on your feet. As long as they meet my needs for comfort, support, and safety, I’m open to trying different options.
Switching gears a bit, how do seasonal changes affect your footwear choices?

Seasonal changes can definitely influence my footwear choices, especially when it comes to keeping my feet comfortable. In warmer months, I prefer shoes made from more breathable materials to help manage heat and moisture. During colder months, I might opt for shoes with a little more coverage or pair them with warmer socks to keep my feet comfortable. Either way, the primary focus remains on comfort and support regardless of the season.
Are there any specific workplace conditions that influence your shoe selection?

Absolutely, the hospital environment plays a big role in my shoe selection. The floors can be slippery, so slip-resistant soles are a must for safety. Given the long hours on my feet and the need to move quickly sometimes, I need shoes that are comfortable and provide good support throughout the day. Additionally, shoes must be easy to clean, as things can get messy in a hospital setting. All these factors are crucial when picking out work shoes.
Now, moving on to how your footwear preference changes when transitioning from work to personal time, can you describe the process you go through when deciding to try a new shoe brand or model?

When I'm thinking about trying a new shoe brand or model, I usually start by doing some research online. I look for reviews from other healthcare professionals or people with similar needs to see what they’ve experienced. Comfort and support are still my top priorities, so I gather as much information as I can on those aspects. I'll also consider recommendations from friends or colleagues who might have tried the shoes. Once I have enough information, I might try them out in a store to get a feel for the fit and comfort before deciding to buy.
What role does price play in your decision-making process for purchasing work shoes?

Price definitely plays a role, but it's not the only factor. I'm willing to invest a bit more in a good pair of shoes if they offer the comfort, support, and durability needed for long shifts. I see it as a worthwhile investment in my well-being and work performance. However, I do look for options that deliver good value for the price, and I'll often watch for sales or discounts to make the purchase more budget-friendly.
Moving on to brand perception and aesthetics, how does brand reputation influence your choice of work shoes?

Brand reputation does influence my choice to some extent because a good reputation often signals reliability in terms of comfort and durability. If a brand is well-regarded among healthcare workers, I'm more likely to trust that their shoes will meet my needs. However, I still consider personal reviews and try to balance reputation with actual feedback from people who’ve used the shoes in similar work conditions to mine. Ultimately, it helps guide my decision but isn't the sole deciding factor.
Are there any shoe brands you associate with quality or style?

When I think of brands associated with quality and comfort, ones like Dansko, Skechers, and Brooks come to mind. These brands are often recommended by fellow nurses for their support and durability during long shifts. For style, brands like Clarks have nice options that also focus on comfort. It’s reassuring to know that these brands are designed with practical needs in mind, especially in demanding work environments like healthcare.
How do you perceive the value of branded shoes versus non-branded ones?

I often find that branded shoes come with more assurance of quality and support, especially if they have a good reputation among people in similar professions. While they might be more expensive, they often offer durability and comfort that can justify the price. Non-branded options can sometimes be hit-or-miss in terms of quality, so I'd be more cautious with those and would probably rely heavily on reviews or experiences from others before trying them. Ultimately, it comes down to whether the features meet my needs and provide good value for the investment.
Has a brand's marketing influenced your decision to choose their shoes? How so?

Marketing can catch my attention, especially if a brand emphasizes comfort and support in their campaigns, which are key qualities I look for. However, it’s usually more about the experiences shared by other healthcare professionals that influence my final decision. A personal testimonial or a recommendation from someone I trust can be more convincing than a marketing message. That said, effective marketing that highlights the practical features I value might prompt me to explore a brand further, but I still rely heavily on reviews and word-of-mouth before making a purchase.
How important is the aesthetic appeal of a shoe when you make a purchase decision?

Aesthetic appeal is somewhat important, but it takes a backseat to comfort and support when it comes to work shoes. I like my shoes to look professional and blend well with my work attire, but I won't compromise on comfort for style. It's nice when shoes are both comfortable and aesthetically pleasing, but the primary focus is on functionality and how well they support me throughout my shifts.
What are the most significant challenges you face with your current footwear?

One of the biggest challenges I face with current footwear is ensuring they maintain their support and comfort throughout long shifts. Over time, even the best shoes can wear down, so they might not offer the same level of support as when they were new. Another challenge is finding shoes that fit perfectly since sizing can vary between brands. Plus, because I'm on my feet so much, it's essential they don't cause any discomfort or blisters, especially when I'm breaking in a new pair. Balancing durability and comfort is always a key concern.
Can you describe a frustrating experience with a work shoe that led you to seek an alternative?

Sure, I remember having a pair that seemed fine at first, but after a couple of weeks, they started to cause pain in my arches and heels. It felt like the cushioning had worn down too quickly and they weren't providing the support I needed for the long hours on my feet. I ended up with sore feet by the end of each shift, which was pretty frustrating. That experience pushed me to look for alternatives with better support and durability, and I started paying closer attention to reviews and recommendations from other nurses who spend similar time on their feet.
What triggers your decision to switch shoe brands or styles?

I usually consider switching shoe brands or styles when I notice my current pair isn't providing the comfort and support I need anymore. If I start experiencing foot pain, fatigue, or discomfort during or after shifts, that's a definite trigger to find something new. Also, if I hear positive reviews or recommendations about a different brand or style from colleagues, I might be inclined to give it a try, especially if many people mention improvement in areas where my current shoes are lacking.
How do you evaluate whether a new shoe is worth trying?

When evaluating whether a new shoe is worth trying, I start by looking at reviews and testimonials from healthcare workers or people with similar jobs. I focus on features like comfort, support, and durability. I also consider if the shoe has slip-resistant soles, which are crucial in my work environment. If possible, I’ll try them on in-store to check how they feel, especially for fit and arch support. If they seem comfortable and have a good reputation, and the price is reasonable for the quality promised, I’m more likely to give them a shot.
What would you change about your current work shoes to better meet your needs?

If I could change one thing about my current work shoes, it would be enhancing their durability. Although they are comfortable initially, over time, they tend to lose their cushioning and support faster than I’d like. It would be great if they could maintain their supportive qualities for a longer period, reducing the need for frequent replacements. Additionally, a more breathable material would help with comfort during longer shifts. These changes would really help in keeping my feet feeling good throughout the day.
What innovations in footwear would you like to see in the future?

In the future, I'd love to see innovations focusing on enhanced durability so that shoes maintain their cushioning and support over a longer period. Customizable support features could be great too, allowing adjustments in arch support or heel cushioning to match individual needs. Breathability is another area for improvement, with materials that keep feet cool and dry without compromising on safety or support. It’d also be nice to have shoes that adapt better to different foot shapes, maybe through adjustable footbeds. These innovations could really make a difference for those of us who rely heavily on our footwear.
How open are you to trying new shoe technologies designed for comfort or support?

I'm quite open to trying new shoe technologies, especially if they're aimed at improving comfort and support. Given the demands of my job, anything that could make long shifts easier on my feet is worth considering. I'm always on the lookout for options that could offer better durability and comfort. Of course, I’d look for reviews and feedback from others to get a sense of how effective the technology is in practice before making a commitment.
What advice would you give to shoe designers to better meet the needs of nurses?

I would advise shoe designers to prioritize comfort and support above all else, as these are crucial for nurses who spend long hours on their feet. Focus on durable materials that maintain cushioning and support over time. Incorporating slip-resistant soles is essential for safety in hospital settings. Breathability is important for keeping feet comfortable during long shifts. It would also be beneficial to have designs that cater to different foot shapes and sizes. Lastly, getting feedback from nurses during the design process could help ensure the shoes meet real-world needs and conditions.
Are there any unmet needs or desires you have regarding footwear that current options don't address?

One unmet need I have is finding shoes that maintain their support and cushioning for extended periods without wearing down quickly. Even reliable brands tend to lose their comfort over time. Additionally, having options that are more customizable to individual foot shapes and arch needs would be great. While many shoes are comfortable at first, they don’t all adapt well to everyone's specific foot structure. Lastly, while functionality comes first, a broader range of styles that still prioritize comfort would be nice, allowing for more personal expression without sacrificing practicality.
How do you foresee your footwear preferences changing over the next few years?

I imagine my footwear preferences will continue to prioritize comfort and support, especially as I spend more years on my feet. As I grow in my career and potentially take on leadership roles, I might look for shoes that offer a blend of professionalism and functionality. I could also see myself leaning more towards options that offer customizability for specific foot needs as my body might require different support over time. Additionally, I might be drawn to eco-friendly materials and technologies if they can meet my practical needs. Overall, comfort will always be key, but I’ll be open to innovations that make my job easier.
Is there anything else you'd like to add about your footwear experiences and preferences?

I think we've covered most of it. Overall, my footwear preferences are all about finding that balance between comfort, support, and durability. Ensuring that I'm comfortable on my feet helps me stay focused and effective at work. While aesthetics are nice, the practical aspects are what truly drive my choices. I'm always open to trying innovations that could improve comfort and reduce foot fatigue, especially given the demands of my job. Having reliable shoes makes all the difference in getting through long shifts with a smile.
What are the key takeaways you hope shoe manufacturers understand about nurses' needs?

I hope shoe manufacturers understand that for nurses, comfort and support are absolutely essential due to the long hours spent on our feet. Durable materials that maintain these qualities over time are crucial. Slip-resistance for safety and breathability for comfort are also very important. Listening to feedback from nurses and incorporating that into the design process can make a big difference. Ultimately, shoes that help us focus on patient care without worrying about foot discomfort are what we need most.
How can shoe companies better support your work-life balance through their products?

Shoe companies can better support work-life balance by creating versatile shoes that provide ample support and comfort for work, while being stylish enough for casual wear outside of work. This would reduce the need to switch footwear between different parts of my day. Also, offering shoes with durable, long-lasting comfort can save time and money on frequent replacements, reducing stress. Collaborating with healthcare professionals to continuously improve and adapt shoes to our changing needs can enhance both work comfort and overall quality of life.
